title: De Moivre's Theorem
description: (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ). Connects powers of complex numbers to multiple angle formulas.

meta.author: De Moivre, Euler (formalized in Lean 4 with Mathlib)

mathlibDependencies.description: exp(θ·I) = cos θ + sin θ·I (Euler's formula)

originalContributions: Double and triple angle formula derivations

overview.historicalContext: Abraham de Moivre (1667-1754) discovered this formula around 1707. It was later popularized by Euler and is essential for finding roots of unity and deriving trigonometric identities.
overview.problemStatement:
**De Moivre's Theorem**:

$$(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)^n = \cos(n\theta) + i\sin(n\theta)$$

for any real θ and natural number n.
overview.proofStrategy: Using Euler's formula e^(iθ) = cos θ + i sin θ, raising both sides to the n-th power gives e^(inθ) = cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ).
keyInsights: Essential for finding n-th roots of complex numbers

conclusion.summary: De Moivre's theorem is elegantly proven via Euler's formula, demonstrating the power of complex exponentials.
